sentence:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion,

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screen time and its negative effects are being primarily overstated. While there are legitimate complaints to be made of excessive screen use, such as it being a deterrant to healthy sleep schedules if used too late at night, many people can control and moderate their screen use in a practical and healthy matter.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screen time and its negative effects are being primarily overstated. While there are legitimate complaints to be made of excessive screen use, such as it being a deterrant to healthy sleep schedules if used too late at night, many people can control and moderate their screen use in a practical and healthy matter. 

Many have never been able to afford books, and with the Amazon Kindle even those that can afford books are choosing alternatives.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screen time and its negative effects are being primarily overstated. While there are legitimate complaints to be made of excessive screen use, such as it being a deterrent to healthy sleep schedules if used too late at night, many people can control and moderate their screen use in a practical and healthy matter. Digital devices and other types of screen use varies in its usage. Some use it for social media, while others use it for work or personal recreation. The more traditional forms of displaying content or information, such as books and paper documents are being phased out, instead being replaced by digital media and content. For the most part, this is a good outcome. Digital documents and media saves paper and physical resources, and can easily be accessed by many. Many have never been able to afford books, and with the Amazon Kindle even those that can afford books are choosing alternatives. Beyond digital books, people can engage with literature through audio books, or even video formats. There are a multitude of different forms of screen use today, many of which have been adopted by countless in the world due to the pandemic, that is beneficial and worthwhile to engage in. The benefits offered by such screen use outweigh the negative consequences and setbacks, but those consequences should still be kept in mind by its users.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screen time and its negative effects are being primarily overstated. While there are legitimate complaints to be made of excessive screen use, such as it being a deterrent to healthy sleep schedules if used too late at night, many people can control and moderate their screen use in a practical and healthy matter. For the most part, this is a good outcome. Digital documents and media saves paper and physical resources, and can easily be accessed by many. Many have never been able to afford books, and with the Amazon Kindle even those that can afford books are choosing alternatives. Beyond digital books, people can engage with literature through audio books, or even video formats. There are a multitude of different forms of screen use today, many of which have been adopted by countless in the world due to the pandemic, that is beneficial and worthwhile to engage in. The benefits offered by such screen use outweigh the negative consequences and setbacks, but those consequences should still be kept in mind by its users.



Intuitively, the benefits of screen time and digital devices vastly exceed their negatives.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screen time and its negative effects are being primarily overstated. While there are legitimate complaints to be made of excessive screen use, such as it being a deterrent to healthy sleep schedules if used too late at night, many people can control and moderate their screen use in a practical and healthy matter. Digital devices and other types of screen use varies in its usage. Some use it for social media, while others use it for work or personal recreation. The more traditional forms of displaying content or information, such as books and paper documents are being phased out, instead being replaced by digital media and content. For the most part, this is a good outcome. Digital documents and media saves paper and physical resources, and can easily be accessed by many. Many have never been able to afford books, and with the Amazon Kindle even those that can afford books are choosing alternatives. Beyond digital books, people can engage with literature through audio books, or even video formats. There are a multitude of different forms of screen use today, many of which have been adopted by countless in the world due to the pandemic, that is beneficial and worthwhile to engage in. The benefits offered by such screen use outweigh the negative consequences and setbacks, but those consequences should still be kept in mind by its users.

Intuitively, the benefits of screen time and digital devices vastly exceed their negatives, but those negatives in turn still exist and pose problems to individuals. I believe those problems can be addressed, and reduced, to lessen the harm incurred to people. For example, excessive screen use may negatively affect the mood of a person, who engages too often online with content that worries them, or worsens their mood. For those individuals, it would be practical to take frequent breaks from screen use, and or to engage with others in person. Likewise, many will still benefit from in person interactions, as screen use may not offer the same types of social benefits that people experience when they meet up with people close to them.

Likewise, many will still benefit from in person interactions, as screen use may not offer the same types of social benefits that people experience when they meet up with people close to them. Going out with friends, or seeing people you know in public is good for the psyche and is a benefit of screen use.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

Many have never been able to afford books, and with the Amazon Kindle even those that can afford books are choosing alternatives. Beyond digital books, people can engage with literature through audio books, or even video formats. There are a multitude of different forms of screen use today, many of which have been adopted by countless in the world due to the pandemic, that is beneficial and worthwhile to engage in. The benefits offered by such screen use outweigh the negative consequences and setbacks, but those consequences should still be kept in mind by its users.

Intuitively, the benefits of screen time and digital devices vastly exceed their negatives, but those negatives in turn still exist and pose problems to individuals. I believe those problems can be addressed, and reduced, to lessen the harm incurred to people. For example, excessive screen use may negatively affect the mood of a person, who engages too often online with content that worries them, or worsens their mood. For those individuals, it would be practical to take frequent breaks from screen use, and or to engage with others in person. Likewise, many will still benefit from in person interactions, as screen use may not offer the same types of social benefits that people experience when they meet up with people close to them. Going out with friends, or seeing people you know in public is good for the psyche, and doing so can be a benefit concurrent with screen use. People can connect with others and form relationships online, choosing to further said relationships in person and outside of online forums. Thus, it is necessary the many in society embrace the integration of screen use and digital media in society. For the benefits screen use incurs to its users will benefit many in their lives, and to deny it is to decrease the benefits available to people around the world.

It is only after such digital media and screen use are both accepted and understood that people can find a middle ground in their usage to maximize its benefits, and minimize its drawbacks.
